awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Novel interactions in novel conditions: consequences of disrupting historical plant-fungal interactions for tree responses to environmental variation
awd_abstract_narration:
When a plant species is stressed by warming or drying climates in an area it has three options: move to a new location that has a suitable climate, develop tolerance to the new climate through evolution or acclimation, or go extinct in the area. However, we now know that all plants exist in association with a highly diverse community of microorganisms (i.e. fungi), which can help plants access water and nutrients in soil. This research will investigate whether tree species can utilize the fungi associated with their root zones to increase their tolerance to drying conditions. The study will also test whether disrupting the historical relationships between plants and the fungi associated with their roots, will benefit or harm tree seedlings as they establish in new areas. Additionally, this project will establish a network of citizen scientists who will aid in collecting root samples from several tree species across the eastern United States. These samples will then be used in a new undergraduate course in which the students use emerging molecular biology and computational tools to identify and map the current distribution of fungal species in forest soils. Together, this new knowledge may help predict how temperate forests will respond to changing environments, and potentially lead to new tools to promote forest health by conserving or manipulating soil microbes. 

For plants, microbial communities in and around roots can mediate access to soil moisture and nutrients. Alterations of these communities may provide an alternative source of phenotypic variation in plant tolerance to environmental changes. As both plant and microbial populations shift their distributions, historical relationships between plant populations, microbial taxa, and abiotic conditions will be disrupted. This project will investigate how novel plant-microbial interactions may affect tree establishment within and beyond current ranges. To accomplish this, the investigator will use a combination of experiments in the field and controlled settings which manipulate tree seedling source population and soil microbial communities, along with and molecular characterization of rhizosphere fungal communities. Specifically, the project will 1) determine whether tree populations are adapted to local microbial communities, and how this compares with adaptation to climatic and edaphic gradients, 2) test whether root-associated microbial communities mediate range expansion and contraction in the face of changing environments, and 3) document how rhizosphere microbial taxa are currently distributed across host ranges, and how these distributions may shift under rapid environmental changes.

por.por_cntn:
Changing climates are pushing species outside of their evolved tolerances; populations must acclimate or adapt to the new conditions or migrate to avoid extinction. However, because plants associate with diverse microbial communities that shape their phenotype, shifts in microbial associations may provide an alternative source of novel climate tolerance. In this project, we sought to understand how shifting microbial associations could affect the abilty of tree seedlings to tolerate heat, drought, and cold stress, using a combination of field and greenhouse experiments. We additionally tested whether populations of trees were locally adapted to their microbial communities, and how these locally adapted relationships changed under environmental stress. Finally, we partnered with communty participants throughout the eastern United States to map the geographic distribution of rhizosphere fungi, a first step in understanding whether tree species will encounter novel fungal associates as both the tree and fungal species shift in their geographic ranges due to climate change.

We found that tree seedlings inoculated with microbial communities sourced from drier, warmer, or colder sites displayed higher survival when facing drought, heat, or cold stress, respectively. The results for drought tolerance were replicated in a controlled greenhouse experiment. Microbially mediated drought and heat tolerance appeared to derive from interactions with arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi, while microbially mediate cold tolerance was not predictable from fungal composition. Understanding microbially mediated climate tolerance may enhance our ability to predict and manage the adaptability of forest ecosystems to changing climates. Moreoever, forest nurseries, which grow seedlings for forest restoration in outdoor beds, already represent a massive, uncontrolled movement of root-associated microbes across landscapes, and could be used to as a tool for the planned pre-inoculation of tree seedlings with microbial associates pre-adapted to future conditions at restoration planting sites.

Furthermore, we partnered with over 1000 community participants to collect over 900 distinct samples of tree roots from across the eastern US. These samples then formed the core of a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) course taught at the University of Wisconsin-Madison four times during this award period. In this course, students (~120 total to date) performed the molecular, bioinformatic, and statistical steps necessary to identify the fungal taxa present on each root sample, and test hypotheses about the environmental factors determining the distribution of individual fungal taxa. We have since used the resulting dataset to test hypotheses about how the fungal communities on individual tree species shifts across geographic and environmental gradients. One key finding is that tree individual host a lower diversity of ectomycorrhizal fungi in sites with higher levels of anthropogenic nitrogen deposition. We also found that a mysterious group of non-mycorrhizal fungal endophytes displayed a strong postive association with site aridity, indicating a potential role in tree drought response that deserves further investigation.

Beyond the scientific results, this project had numerous broader impacts through outreach and education. Over 1000 community participants were introduced to basic concepts of plant and fungal biology, forestry, and climate change through our community science project, with many of the particpants school age children in rural areas. The undergradautes in the linked Plant Microbiomes course gained authentic research experiences at a scale much larger than can be achieved through individual mentoring in our research group. Finally, this project supported several early career scientists as undergraduate research assistants, graduate students, and post-doctoral scholars.
